abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Gas Seep Harvesting
            Project for Timor-Leste were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high,
            the Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the significant impacts of the realization of the
            risk, even if the probability is low, should be seriously
            considered. The risk of lower than expected gas yields was
            rated as modest based on the feasibility study. Due to the
            relatively low cost pilot nature and the urgency to provide
            electricity services to the poor, the decision was made to
            implement the project to take the risk. However, the
            impacts, should the risk occur, were so high that stronger
            confirmation of this critical project assumption should have
            been made during preparation. There is a need to ensure
            adequate implementation capacity when the Bank embarks in a
            small country. The required support to capacity of people
            and environments need to be carefully identified and
            sufficiently addressed not only regarding project
            management, but also across the whole range of skills
            including procurement and financial management. The Bank
            should be more flexible to the changes in Government
            strategy to power development in the project area. As soon
            as the Bank learned that the national power development plan
            included the national transmission lines covering the
            project areas, which making the project redundant, the Bank
            could have restructured or even cancelled the project.
